6b, which corresponds to the bJES uncertainty, lies close to the vertical line in Fig. 6a, i.e

Most notably, this would also result in a large correlation of the measurements, similar to that observed for the one-dimensional analyses shown in Fig. 6c

Instead, the cuts-based analysis exploits the fact that signal events tend to have higher values of \(H_{\rm T}\) and \(N_{\rm V}\) than do background events, as shown in Fig. 1
caption: Figure 1: Unit-normalized distributions of the 12 variables used in the BDT discriminant

mentions: Their effects on the \(\ell\)+jets and dilepton measurements are listed in Table 3, together with the result of the combination of the two channels discussed in Sect
The resulting sizes of all uncertainties and their sum in quadrature are given in Table 3

The results of the \(t\bar{t}\to\) lepton+jets and \(t\bar{t}\to\) dilepton analyses listed in Table 3 are combined using the Best Linear Unbiased Estimate (BLUE (Best Linear Unbiased Estimate)) method [75; 76], implemented as described in Refs
Some uncertainty sources in Table 3, such as the uncertainty related to the choice of MC (Monte Carlo) generator for signal events, contain only a single component
For uncertainty sources that contain multiple components such as the JES (jet energy scale) uncertainty described in Appendix A, the correlations given in Table 3 differ from \(\rho=\pm 1\)
The list of all uncertainties of the combined result, together with the correlation of the measurements for each group of uncertainties, is provided in Table 3
caption: Their separate effects on the fitted top quark mass are summed in quadrature to determine the total jet energy scale uncertainty given in Table 3

mentions: The numbers of events observed and expected after the above selections are reported in Table 1 for the \(\ell\)+jets and dilepton final states

The different expected statistical uncertainties on \(m_{\rm top}\) for the samples with different numbers of \(b\)-tagged jets, which are obtained from samples containing similar numbers of events (see Table 1), are mainly a consequence of the different resolution on \(m_{\rm top}\).

As for the \(\ell\)+jets channel, the different expected statistical uncertainties on \(m_{\rm top}\) for the samples with different numbers of \(b\)-tagged jets, which are obtained from samples containing similar numbers of events (see Table 1), are mainly a consequence of the different resolution on \(m_{\rm top}\).
